subject: Re: Vam Pro issue - haptic effects sometimes stay on for several seconds longer than intended.
description_text:
Hi there,

Have you been able to review my previous email?

I wanted to update you that the same issues are present with the Vam Pros in the Simsonn software, even with no game input just simply pressing the vibration button to test the motors sometimes gets stuck on and instead of a quick buz it carries on until I click it again and it stops.

Currently the haptics are useless because of these issues. Your help is appreciated.

Kind regards,
Ryan.
________________________________
From: Ryan Burns <ryanoceros92@hotmail.co.uk>
Sent: 29 July 2025 17:44
To: support@simsonn.com <support@simsonn.com>
Subject: Vam Pro issue - haptic effects sometimes stay on for several seconds longer than intended.

Hi there,
I recently purchased the Pro X Ultimate pedals along with the Vam Pro haptic accessories. I've set everything up, and while the hardware appears to be working correctly, I'm encountering an issue with the Vam Pro effects in SimHub.
When testing, the haptic effects sometimes stay on for several seconds longer than intended. For example, I tested the gear change effect, which is supposed to produce an 80ms pulse. However, it occasionally continues vibrating for 2-3 seconds. This issue seems to happen across multiple effects not just gear change.
The problem becomes more noticeable when using multiple effects at once, as one effect tends to get stuck in each corner, making the overall feedback inaccurate and distracting.
I’ve recorded a video showing this behaviour, please let me know if you’d like me to send it.
Any help resolving this issue would be greatly appreciated.
Kind regards,
Ryan

conversations.body_text: Hi Ryan Burns,  First, please upgrade to the latest 2.1.0 software version and ensure your firmware is 2.0.2. Next, make sure the pedal’s USB cable is connected directly to the rear USB 3.0 port of your PC instead of using a USB hub, to avoid power supply issues or unstable connections. Additionally, please let us know the brand of your wheelbase and check if your PC is properly grounded, as poor grounding may cause EMI interference issues.      To address EMI (Electromagnetic Interference) issues, please follow the steps below to improve device stability and USB connection reliability:     1.    Ensure proper grounding: Make sure the computer is connected to a three-prong outlet with a reliable ground. Two-prong plugs do not provide grounding.     2.    Control box grounding: Use a green shielding wire to connect the metal housing (such as a copper post or screw) of the control box to any metal screw on the pedal. Ensure the contact point is paint-free and conductive.     3.    Base grounding (e.g., Fanatec / MOZA): It’s recommended to connect the metal part of the base to the PC chassis or an external ground to discharge static buildup.     4.    Avoid high-interference zones: Keep USB cables away from high-voltage power lines or adapters; route cables separately where possible.     5.    Use direct USB connection: Connect devices directly to a rear USB 3.0 port on the PC instead of using unpowered or low-quality USB hubs.     6.    Use USB cables with ferrite cores: If needed, switch to high-quality USB cables with ferrite beads to reduce high-frequency interference.     7.    Keep software and firmware updated: Ensure SIMSONN Manager and firmware are updated to the latest version, as some updates include EMI handling improvements.     8.    Use a USB isolator: If the above methods don’t resolve the issue, using a USB isolator is recommended. It physically separates the USB power and data lines, effectively shielding the control device from EMI sources.     https://github.com/SHWotever/SimHub/wiki/USB-Issues-Troubleshooting https://support.gomezsimindustries.com/portal/en/kb/articles/understanding-emi-and-grounding  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LciAFDFWJ1w

Hi there,
Thank you for the detailed response.
I have confirmed that I am using the latest version of the Simsonn software, and my firmware is up to date. My PC has six USB 3.0 ports on the rear motherboard panel, and I have tested all of them directly with the pedal’s USB cable. Unfortunately, the issue still occurs regardless of which port is used.
I live in the UK, and my PC is powered through a grounded three-prong plug. According to your website, the control box is shielded, so EMI should not be a significant concern in this case.
My wheelbase is a Thrustmaster T300, and it is connected to the PC via its own USB cable.
I tested the issue again today. Within the Simsonn software, under the pedal feedback settings, there is a "vibrate" button to test the motor. At first, it works correctly with a short vibration. However, after a few presses, the motor gets stuck and continues to vibrate until I manually click the button again. This behaviour closely matches what I’m experiencing in-game, where effects occasionally get stuck and do not stop as expected.
Please let me know if there are any additional steps I should try.
Kind regards,
Ryan

Hi there,
I’ve checked the VKB tool and can see that only the X, Y, and Z axis data is showing. However, I’m still experiencing the issue with the effects getting stuck.
It seems to be happening less frequently now, and the vibrations don’t last as long as before, but the problem is still occurring intermittently.

Hi Ryan Burns,   Is the game experiencing intermittent interruptions? Please try testing with the wheelbase power turned off to see if the interruptions still occur.

Hi there,
I’m able to replicate the issue even with no games running and only the Simsonn software open. Nothing else is plugged into my PC during testing.
Given this, I don’t believe the issue is related to the game or my wheelbase.
I’ve attached a video showing a test I ran where I repeatedly clicked the vibrate button. In the video, you can hear it working normally for the first two clicks, but on the third click, the vibration gets stuck and continues.
Please let me know what you recommend next.
Best regards,
Ryan

________________________________

Hi Ryan Burns,   I recommend uninstalling SIMSONN Manager from your computer and downloading the 2.1.0 version from our official website for installation. Then update the firmware with proxultra.sfu. This issue may have been caused by the stop command from the main chip to the secondary chip being lost, preventing it from stopping in time. The new software version should have fixed this problem. In our tests, we clicked dozens of times, and the issue did not reoccur. Please follow this path for the manual update: Settings → Update → Manual Firmware Update → pedals → firmware → proxultra.sfu, and then test again.       https://www.simsonn.com/pages/download
